questions.text: A 45-year-old female complains of morning stiffness lasting over an hour and pain in her hands and wrists. On examination, there is swelling and tenderness of multiple small joints in her hands. Laboratory results show a positive rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies. X-ray reveals soft tissue swelling and early joint space narrowing. Which of the following joint involvement patterns is most characteristic of this condition?

choices.text: Symmetrical involvement of small joints, particularly the MCP and PIP joints
Asymmetrical involvement of small joints, particularly the MCP and PIP joints
Symmetrical involvement of the DIP joints
Asymmetrical involvement of the DIP joints

questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation and investigations suggest Rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which typically presents with symmetrical polyarthritis, primarily affects the small joints of the hands, particularly the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints.
  • Symmetrical joint involvement is a hallmark of RA, distinguishing it from other forms of arthritis.
  • Distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint involvement is more characteristic of osteoarthritis or psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with joint pain and swelling, particularly in her hands and wrists, over the past 6 months. She has a family history of autoimmune diseases, and laboratory tests show positive rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-citrullinated protein antibodies (anti-CCP). Which of the following statements is true regarding the etiopathogenesis of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Crystal disposition in the joint spaces leads to joint inflammation
Presence of HLA-DR β 1 is strongly associated with this condition
Joint destruction occurs due to mechanical damage to the articular cartilage
Pregnancy can aggravate the symptoms of this condition

questions.solution:
• Based on the clinical features and investigation findings, this patient most likely has Rheumatoid arthritis, which is strongly associated with the presence of HLA-DR β1.
  • Citrullinated protein in the joints makes the protein more immunogenic, leading to autoimmunity and causing rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Rheumatoid arthritis

Epidemiology

Male to female ratio - 1:3

Peaks between 25 and 55 years

Remains constant between 55 and 75

Genetics

  • Strongly associated with the HLA-DRβ1 gene (Option B)
  • Higher concordance in monozygotic twins

Triggers and suppressors

  • Cigarette smoking and infections can trigger RA in genetically predisposed individuals by citrullination of proteins.
  • RA may remit during pregnancy and can first appear postpartum due to immune suppression and hormonal changes. (Option D ruled out)

Pathogenesis


 

Crystal disposition in the joint spaces leads to joint inflammation (Option A), which is seen in crystal arthropathies such as Gouts, Calcium pyrophosphate deposition disorder, basic calcium phosphate deposition arthropathy and calcium oxalate arthropathy.

 

 

Joint destruction due to mechanical damage of the articular cartilage (Option C) is seen in osteoarthritis. Inflammation, along with inadequate repair, results in degenerative changes in the affected joints.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient with a long-standing history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with specific difficulties in her left hand. She reports difficulty extending the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint of her middle finger and flexing at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following deformities is most consistent with the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Swan neck deformity is associated with rheumatoid arthritis, and it presents with

  • Proximal interphalangeal joint extension (PIP) - difficulty in flexion of PIP.
  • Distal interphalangeal flexion (DIP) - difficulty in extension of DIP.

 

Articular deformity and changes in rheumatoid arthritis

Articular changes

Autoimmune inflammation mediates pannus formation, eroding the articular cartilage and bone.

Metacarpophalangeal joint (MCP), proximal interphalangeal joint and wrist joint are involved

Deformities

 

 

Swan neck deformity (Option B)

  • Extension at proximal interphalangeal joint (PIP)
  • Flexion at the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP): The DIP joint is not involved; flexion occurs due to tension on the tendons attached to the base of Distal phalanges

Boutonniere deformity (Option A ruled out)

  • Flexion at PIP and extension at DIP
  • Both swan neck and boutonniere deformity can occur in different fingers of the same hand.

Z-line deformity (Option C ruled out)

  • Subluxation of the first metacarpophalangeal joint.
  • Hyperextension of interphalangeal joint.

 

Mallet finger deformity (Option D) involves an inability to extend the DIP joint due to a tendon injury without affecting the PIP joint. It is usually a sports injury and is not seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with joint pain and morning stiffness lasting more than one hour. Based on the EULAR classification criteria for rheumatoid arthritis, which of the following combinations of clinical, serological, and laboratory findings is most likely to lead to a definitive diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis?

choices.text: Swelling in 3 small joints, positive anti-citrullinated protein antibodies (ACPA) at high titers, and elevated C-reactive protein (CRP), symptoms for 8 weeks
Swelling in 1 large joint, positive rheumatoid factor at low titers, normal ESR, and symptoms for 4 weeks
Swelling in 6 small joints, negative ACPA, elevated ESR, and symptoms for 5 weeks
Swelling in 4 large joints, positive ACPA at low titers, normal CRP, and symptoms for 12 weeks

questions.solution:
To meet the EULAR classification criteria for rheumatoid arthritis, a score of 6 or more points is required, based on a combination of joint involvement, serology, acute-phase reactants, and symptom duration:

  1. Joint Involvement:
    • Involvement of 3 small joints scores 2 points.
    • Involvement of 1 large joint or 4 large joints scores 1 point.
  2. Serology:
    • High-titer ACPA or rheumatoid factor (RF) gives 3 points.
    • Low-titer ACPA or RF gives 2 points.
    • Negative ACPA or RF gives 0 points.
  3. Acute-phase reactants:
    • Elevated CRP or ESR gives 1 point.
    • Normal CRP or ESR gives 0 points.
  4. Duration of symptoms:
    • ≥6 weeks gives 1 point.
    • <6 weeks gives 0 points.

  • According to the ACR-EULAR 2010 criteria, patients with clinical synovitis (swelling) in at least one joint should be evaluated for rheumatoid arthritis, particularly when other conditions cannot explain the synovitis.
  • A score of ≥6/10 across categories A-D is required to classify a patient as having definite RA.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of working in coal mines presents with progressive shortness of breath and a chronic cough. He reports that years ago, he was diagnosed with a joint condition that caused swelling and stiffness, particularly in his hands and wrists. Laboratory testing reveals he is positive for HLA-DR4. A chest X-ray shows multiple rounded opacities in both lung fields. A lung biopsy showed the following picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's history of a joint condition, likely rheumatoid arthritis (given the positive HLA-DR4), combined with long-term occupational exposure to coal dust and the presence of rounded lung nodules on X-ray and biopsy, suggests Caplan syndrome.

 

Caplan syndrome:

  • It is characterised by the formation of multiple well-defined pulmonary nodules, typically located in the lung periphery, in individuals with rheumatoid arthritis who have been exposed to inorganic dust.
  • These nodules exhibit pathological features similar to rheumatoid nodules, including central necrosis, surrounding palisading histiocytes, and a peripheral rim of lymphocytes and plasma cells.
  • This syndrome is specifically associated with coal worker's pneumoconiosis but can also occur in other forms of pneumoconiosis.

 

 

Secondary Sjögren's Syndrome (Option B) occurs in individuals with a pre-existing autoimmune disease, such as rheumatoid arthritis or lupus. It primarily involves dryness of the eyes and mouth (sicca symptoms) due to autoimmune destruction of the lacrimal and salivary glands.

 

Felty syndrome (Option C) is a rare complication of longstanding rheumatoid arthritis, characterised by the triad of RA, splenomegaly, and neutropenia. It does not involve pulmonary opacities or occupational exposure, pulmonary nodules, or occupational lung exposure.

 

Lofgren syndrome (Option D) is an acute presentation of sarcoidosis, marked by the triad of erythema nodosum, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and arthritis (usually in the ankles). It is not related to the patient’s coal mining history or lung opacities.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with multiple subcutaneous nodules on his arms and back, along with joint pain and stiffness primarily affecting his hands and knees. He has erythema nodosum and a positive family history of similar conditions. Which of the following is a common ocular extra-articular manifestation associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
• This patient’s presentation suggests a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which is characterised by joint inflammation and can also manifest through various extra-articular features.
  • Common extra-articular manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis include subcutaneous nodules, erythema nodosum, and ocular complications (keratoconjunctivitis sicca).
  • Rheumatoid/subcutaneous nodules are the most common extra-articular manifestation of RA.

 

Extra-articular manifestations of Rheumatoid arthritis

Skin

Non-tender Rheumatoid nodules (most common), Livedo reticularis, Pyoderma gangrenosum

Rheumatoid nodules and Livedo reticularis

 

Pyoderma gangrenosum

Ocular

Keratoconjunctivitis sicca (Option A), episcleritis, scleritis

CVS

Pericarditis, myocarditis, Arrhythmias, ischemic heart disease

Respiratory

Pleuritis, Interstitial lung disease, Caplan syndrome

Salivary glands

Xerostomia, periodontitis

Renal

Glomerulonephritis, Secondary amyloidosis

Other features

Hyperandrogenism, anaemia of chronic disease

Extra-articular manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis" data-author="" data-hash="9215" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/4hB1a2ekGTQe0hiSubyz1744361187.png" />

 

Uveitis (Option B), iritis (Option C) and iridocyclitis (Option D) are not associated with RA.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with bilateral pain, swelling, and stiffness in his hands and wrists for the past 4 months. His symptoms are worse in the morning and improve throughout the day. The physical exam shows synovitis in the metacarpophalangeal joints. Considering the high specificity for rheumatoid arthritis, which initial investigation is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation suggests rheumatoid arthritis (RA), characterised by morning stiffness, symmetrical joint involvement, and synovitis in the hands.
  • The most appropriate initial investigation to support this diagnosis is the anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibody test, which is highly specific for rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Causes of positive test for RF

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Sjogren's syndrome
  • Vasculitis such as polyarteritis nodosa
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Cryoglobulinemia
  • Chronic liver disease
  • Infections- tuberculosis, bacterial endocarditis, infectious mononucleosis, leprosy, syphilis, leishmaniasis.
  • Malignancies
  • Old age (5% women aged above 60)

 

Investigations and monitoring of RA:

To establish diagnosis

  • Clinical criteria
  • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP)
  • Ultrasound or magnetic resonance imaging (Option D ruled out)
  • ACPA and RF (both are positive in about 70% of the cases)

To monitor disease damage

  • X-rays
  • Functional assessment

To monitor disease activity and drug efficacy

  • Pain (visual analogue scale)
  • Early morning stiffness (minutes)
  • Joint tenderness
  • Joint swelling
  • DAS28 score (Disease activity score 28)
  • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein

To monitor drug safety

  • Urinalysis
  • Full blood count
  • Chest X-ray
  • Urea and creatinine
  • Liver function test

 

DAS28 score:

  • It is commonly used to evaluate disease activity, treatment response, and the need for biological therapy in rheumatoid arthritis.
  • It calculates the number of swollen and tender joints in the upper limbs and knees, combining this with the ESR and the patient's self-assessment of their arthritis using a visual analogue scale.

 

Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) test (Option A) is primarily used to diagnose systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and other connective tissue diseases, not RA. Although ANA can occasionally be positive in RA, it is not a specific or reliable test for this condition.

 

Synovial fluid analysis (Option C) helps rule out other conditions, such as infection or crystal arthropathy but is not the initial investigation for rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents with significant joint pain, stiffness, and swelling affecting multiple joints. Her Disease Activity Score (DAS28) is 5.4, indicating high disease activity. She has not responded adequately to lifestyle modifications and NSAIDs. Which medication is considered this patient's first-line disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD)?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate is the first-line DMARD for patients with high disease activity, as indicated by the DAS28 score of 5.4 (moderate to severe RA). It effectively manages rheumatoid arthritis and slows disease progression.

 

  • The DAS score typically ranges from 0 to 10.
    • Low Disease Activity: DAS < 3.2
    • Moderate Disease Activity: DAS 3.2 - 5.1
    • High Disease Activity: DAS > 5.1
  • A decrease in the DAS score indicates improvement, while an increase suggests worsening disease activity.


 

Management of Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA):

Treatment Goals:

  • Early Intervention: Start aggressive therapy to prevent joint damage and disability.
  • Achieve low disease activity or remission.

 

Treatment Categories: RA treatment encompasses four main categories:

  • Nonsteroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs): Adjunctive therapy for symptom management. Chronic use causes side effects like GI issues and renal impairment.
  • Glucocorticoids can provide rapid control of disease activity during exacerbations.
    • Low-dose prednisone (5–10 mg/d) may be used alongside DMARD therapy.
  • Disease-Modifying Antirheumatic Drugs (DMARDs):
    • Conventional DMARDs:
      • Methotrexate: First-line DMARD is taken weekly with folic acid to mitigate side effects.
      • Leflunomide (Option C)
      • Sulfasalazine (Option A)
      • Hydroxychloroquine (Option D)
    • A commonly used conventional DMARD combination is triple therapy with:
      • Methotrexate
      • Sulfasalazine
      • Hydroxychloroquine
    • Biologic DMARDs:
      • TNF inhibitors:
        • Etanercept
        • Adalimumab
        • Tocilizumab
        • Infliximab
        • Certolizumab
      • IL-1 receptor Antagonists: Anakinra
      • Other Biologics:
        • Abatacept (CD-80/86 inhibitor)
        • Rituximab (CD-20 inhibitor)
        • Tocilizumab (IL-6 receptor antagonist)
  • Targeted synthetic DMARDs:
    • JAK Inhibitors:
      • Tofacitinib
      • Baricitinib
    • They target intracellular signalling pathways and can be used alone or with methotrexate. Potential side effects include elevated liver enzymes, neutropenia, and an increased risk of thromboembolism and infections.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient with rheumatoid arthritis presents with persistent joint pain and swelling despite being on methotrexate and low-dose prednisolone for the past six months. Her Disease Activity Score (DAS28) is 5.4, indicating high disease activity. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Given the patient's high DAS28 score and inadequate response to methotrexate alone, initiating oral triple therapy (methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine) is the most appropriate next step.

 

  • The DAS score typically ranges from 0 to 10.
    • Low Disease Activity: DAS < 3.2
    • Moderate Disease Activity: DAS 3.2 - 5.1
    • High Disease Activity: DAS > 5.1
  • A decrease in the DAS score indicates improvement, while an increase suggests worsening disease activity.


 

Management Algorithm of Rheumatoid Arthritis:

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with rheumatoid arthritis comes for evaluation of remission after six months of treatment. According to the ACR/EULAR remission criteria, which of the following is not true?

choices.text: Simplified Disease Activity Index (SDAI) score of ≤ 3.2

questions.solution:
According to the ACR/EULAR remission criteria, the C-reactive protein (CRP) level must be ≤ 1 mg/dL, not ≤ 3 mg/dL.

 

ACR/EULAR Provisional Definition of Remission in Rheumatoid Arthritis:

To be classified as in remission at any time point, a patient must meet all of the following criteria:

  • Tender Joint Count: ≤ 1
  • Swollen Joint Count: ≤ 1
  • C-Reactive Protein (CRP): ≤ 1 mg/dL
  • Patient Global Assessment: ≤ 1 (on a 0–10 scale)

(or)

  • Simplified Disease Activity Index (SDAI) score of ≤ 3.3

 

Disease Activity Score 28 (DAS28): Used to assess the activity of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). It evaluates disease severity based on the following components:

  • Tender Joint Count: The number of swollen or tender joints out of a possible 28.
  • Swollen Joint Count: The number of swollen joints.
  • Patient Global Assessment: On a scale of 0-100.
  • Acute Phase Reactants: C-reactive protein (CRP) or erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).

The DAS28 score ranges from 0 to 10, with lower scores indicating less disease activity.

  • Remission: DAS28 < 2.6
  • Low Disease Activity: DAS28 2.6–3.2
  • Moderate Disease Activity: DAS28 3.2–5.1
  • High Disease Activity: DAS28 > 5.1
